Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Okay lets tackle this problem step by step First I need to understand the task properly The goal is to analyze the event log of customer support tickets to find cases with unusually long resolution times and figure out why those delays are happening There are three main steps here identify the delayed cases find the root causes and then suggest improvements

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Starting with the first task identifying which cases have significantly longer total resolution times To do this Ill need to calculate the total time each case ticket took from Receive Ticket to Close Ticket Lets see the data provided Looking at the table

Text: Case 101 Received on 2024 03 01 0800 Closed on the same day at 1015 So total time is about 2 hours and 15 minutes Case 102 Received on 2024 03 01 0805 Closed on 2024 03 02 0915 Thats over 25 hours next day at 915 so 25h10m Case 103 From 810 to 930 on the same day Thats around 1 hour 20 minutes Case 104 Received 820 closed on the next day at 830 Total time is about 24 hours and 10 minutes so roughly a day Case 105 Start at 825 and ends on the third day at 930 Thats over two days around 53 hours or so

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Comparing each case s duration to that average Case 101 2 25 vs 20 4 much shorter Case 102 25 hours above average Since average is 20 4 so 25 is a bit above Case 104 is 24 also above average Case 105 is way above 49 So the most delayed cases are clearly Case 105 then 104 then 102 But significantly longer might require seeing standard deviations or just which are outliers Since 105 is over 49h compared to others except 104 and 102 which are over 24h So perhaps 105 is especially delayed But 104 is about 24h approx a full day 102 is 25h But since in some cases like 103 and 101 are done in a few hours So significantly would likely consider cases with much longer durations For example 105 is 49 hours which is twice as long as 104 So probably case 105 is the most problematic Cases 102 and 104 also take more than a day which might be considered longer than average The question says significantly longer than average so maybe all cases with total time way above average The average was around 20 hours so cases like 102 25h104 24h10549h might be considered above Perhaps 105 is the most but lets see So first step Identify the cases with longer times The user probably wants to know which one are abnormally long So I can note Cases 102 took over a day 1 day 1 hour 104 took about a day 24h10m but 105 took almost 50 hours about 2 days Thus 105 is the most delayed followed by 104 then 102 Hence the first task s answer would list these cases maybe 102 104 105 as significant

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Now moving to the second task Determine root causes Need to look at each of those cases and see why they took so long Starting with Case 105 first since its the slowest

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at case 105 Timeline 2024 03 01 0825 Receive 0835 triaged so 10 mins 0900 assigned 25 minutes later 0910 investigate started so 10 mins after assigned Then At 1000 Escalate to Level 2 so 50 minutes after investigation started Wait let me check Investigate begins at 0910 then next activity is 1000 escalate So from 910 to 1000 is 50 minutes presumably time spent investigating before escalation Then next activity on 2024 03 02 at 1400 which is the next day s 200 PM there s another Investigate Issue Wait so between escalating and next activity there is a wait time of almost 28 hours Because escalate at 1000 on day1 and next action on day2 at 1400 Wait that s 28 hours Let me compute From March 1 1000 AM to March 2 200 PM is 28 hours because next day 10 AM would be 24 hours so 4h is 28 Wait that seems like a long delay between Escalate and Re investigation Wait that s a big chunk of time

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Similarly in case 104 let s see Case 104 s timeline Received on 820 Triage at 900 Assigned at 930 Investigate starts at 1300 so 3 5 hours after assignment Wait from 930 AM to 1 PM is 3 5 hours then resolves next day at 800 AM From investigation at 100 PM to resolve next day 800 AM is 19h assuming 24h minus 13h   Wait from 1300 to 0800 next day is 19 hours from 13 to 24 is 11h plus 8h So total 19 5h Then Resolve to Close is 30 minutes Wait but maybe the big delay here is after investigate The investigate started at 1pm then the next step is resolving at 8AM next day which is 19 hours later so maybe during that time the agent took too long to close it maybe no escalation but just slow processing Also in case 104 the assignment happened at 930 then they didnt start investigating until 1 pm 3 5 hours of delay between assign and investigate That seems like a long waiting time before they even start working on it That could be a cause of delay

Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: Also Case 102 Case 102 timeline Escalation after being assigned to Level 1 assigned at 900 then escalate at 1130 AM So 2 5 hours Then after escalate the investigate next day at 2 PM March 1 1130 AM to March 1 2 PM is 2 5 hours Wait no March is 1st until 1130 AM to 2 PM same day Wait then resolve at 9AM next day March 2nd 900 AM So from escalation at 1130 on day1 to next investigation at 2 PM same day which is 2 5h then investigation to Resolve is from 2 PM to next day 9 AM Thats 19h again similar to case 104 Wait maybe the escalation itself wasnt the issue but the time between investigate and resolve Wait let me look again for 102 After escalation at 1130 AM March1 then they had an Investigate at 1400 2 PM Then Resolve is at 9 AM next day So the investigation starts at 2PM then maybe the investigation took over 19h until resolve at 9AM next day Wait but the activity is Investigate Issue then next is Resolve So maybe the investigation step took longer Alternatively perhaps theres a wait between activities not accounted for Wait for case 102 perhaps the main slow down was between escalate and investigate Lets see Case 102 escalate was at 1130 AM on day1 March1 Then next activity is investigate at 1400 PM 2 PM next is 2 5h later Then from 1400 to resolve at 9 next day s morning The time between investigate and resolve would be from 14 next day 9 AM is 19 hours Hmm So that s a possible point Wait in case 102 after 2 pm investigation the resolve is next day 9 AM 19 hours until resolve That s a whole night perhaps the team didnt work after hours Or if they are supposed to work 8 5 then maybe the processing happens during the next day Same in case 105 after 2 pm on day2 the next day after escalate the investigation to resolve takes time but the next steps are over the night but maybe that s standard working hours Not sure the business hours here

the Level 2 has to start their own investigation which is time consuming So it might be inherent to more complex issues needing escalation but the process can be optimized

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So possible factors are 1 Excessive delays between when a task is assigned escalated and when the next action occurs ex Case 104 had a 3 5 hour delay between assignment and starting investigation and Case 105 had a day plus delay after escalation 2 Escalations introduce significant added time and if those delays between escalation and next activity are not managed properly it balloons the total time 3 Some steps taking too long such as the investigation in Level 2 taking too much time eg in case 102 from investigate to resolve was 19 hours but maybe the next working day processing is okay if that s typical but 28 hours in Case 105 s escalate investigation is unusual Additionally in case 104 the main delay is between Investigate at 1300 and Resolve at 0800 next day so 19 hours If the team is only working standard hours perhaps this is overlapping into the next working day so maybe it s acceptable but if they need to resolve faster then that s an issue Alternatively if they can process quicker that would help Moreover looking at cases without escalations case 101 and 103 finish quite quickly The ones that require escalation take much longer Thus the presence of an escalation path may inherently add more time but especially when combined with waits between steps

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So the root causes are likely a combination of Delayed start times for tasks assign to agent not leading to immediate investigation Long waiting periods after an escalation before work resumes on the ticket Extended investigation times post escalation

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now moving onto third task how do these factors cause delays and what can be done The first issue is delays between activity assignments For instance after a ticket is assigned to a Level 1 agent they might not begin working on it promptly Case 104 waited 3 5 hours This is probably due to the agent s workload or lack of priority handling Agents might not prioritize new tickets quickly or may have other tasks Second after escalation if the next team Level 2 is overloaded or doesn t have enough capacity the tickets sit idle until someone gets to them The 28 hour delay in Case 105 is critical here as it could be that Level 2 was busy but the process for escalating tickets needs better prioritization Third if the investigation steps particularly in Level 2 require costly or time consuming activities like needing more info or multiple rounds of troubleshooting that adds time

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Recommendations 1 Reduce delays between assignment and first action Implement a rule that agents must start investigating within X hours eg 1 hour after being assigned Maybe introduction of a first response goal Monitor and address reasons for delays like poor workload balance on Level 1 2 Streamline escalation process and improve handoff procedures Ensure that escalated tickets are prioritized immediately by the Level 2 team Maybe use automated alerts or prioritized queues Standardize communication tools between Level 1 and Level 2 so that the handoff is smoother reducing confusion or redundant investigation 3 Improve availability of escalation resources Staff sufficient Level 2 agents to handle escalated tickets promptly The long delay in Case 105 suggests that Level 2 might be understaffed or over capacity Ensure Level 2 has access to resources or training to resolve issues faster If they need more time because they lack knowledge providing better training or docs could help 4 Set time limits on individual steps and monitor through process mining For example investigating should not take more than Y hours If it does escalate to a supervisor early Use analytics to identify tasks prone to delays and apply feedback to agents or process 5 Introduce an auto escalation mechanism if tasks aren t handled within SLAs If a ticket hasn t been investigated within 2 hours of assignment it automatically escalates or an alert is raised to management Monitor bottlenecks through KPIs like SLA adherence and cycle times per activity 6 Review the necessity and efficiency of escalations Do all escalated cases take about the same time Perhaps some cases can be resolved faster with improved Level 1 training Maybe some escalations are unnecessary if Level 1 could handle them if given more resources or protocols Additionally in Case 105 having two Investigate steps after escalation suggests maybe the Level 2 team needs to do a full reassessment rather than building on Level 1 s work leading to duplication Ensuring that escalate passes along all current information to cut down redundant work

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: In summary the biggest issues are delays between assigning tickets and starting work after escalation and possibly the process around handling escalated cases being too slow or not well coordinated Addressing these steps with better management staffing and process design should reduce the cycle time
